source_articles.title: Thomas S. Meier Obituary October 6, 2025 - kramergraufuneralhomes.com
source_articles.body:
Thomas S. “Tom” “Quag Meier” Meier, age 61, of Lancaster, passed away on Monday, October 6, 2025, at St. Mary’s Hospital in Madison, WI. He was born on May 14, 1964, in Prairie du Chien, the son of LaVerne and Norma (Myers) Meier. Tom graduated from Cassville High School in 1982. He furthered his education at Southwest Wisconsin Technical College in Fennimore where he earned a degree in auto mechanics. Tom moved to Madison and worked as an auto mechanic and later, in 2013, moved back to Lancaster. He worked as an over the road truck driver and finished his working career at Saputo. Tom enjoyed riding his motorcycle and would often take spontaneous trips hundreds of miles away. He also enjoyed hunting, fishing and watching the Green Bay Packers. Tom dearly loved spending time with his siblings, nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. He was always willing to lend a hand and always had a smile and a positive outlook. Tom will be greatly missed.
Survivors include his siblings: Gary (Barb) Meier, Deforest, Mark (Kathleen) Meier, Asbury, IA, Mike (Cheryl) Meier, Beetown, Sheila (Randy) Hook, Phillips, Jan (Ken) Breuer, Lancaster, Kim (Randy) Wallin, Lancaster, Tony (Janell) Meier, Glen Haven; many nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews; other relatives and many friends.
In addition to his parents, Thomas was preceded in death by his stepmother, Shirley; a brother, David; and a nephew, Chris Meier.
Funeral services will be held on Saturday, October 18, 2025, at 1:00 p.m., at Kramer-Grau Funeral Homes & Crematory in Lancaster with Pastor Mark Hoehne officiating. Private family burial will be held at a later date. Family and friends may visit on Saturday from 10:00 a.m. until the time of services at the funeral home. A Celebration of Life will be held at a later date. In lieu of plants and flowers, the family suggests memorials be given in memory of Tom to the Glen Haven Fire Department, Lancaster Rescue Squad and/or Biolife.

source_articles.title: The U.S.'s strongest tornado in 12 years hit North Dakota in June, National Weather Service says - CBS News
source_articles.body:
The U.S.'s strongest tornado in 12 years hit North Dakota in June, National Weather Service says
A deadly tornado that ripped through a rural city in North Dakota in June has been upgraded to an EF-5, the National Weather Service said Monday, marking the first U.S. twister with an EF-5 rating in 12 years.
The federal agency's Grand Forks, North Dakota, facility estimates the twister that touched down in the southeast city of Enderlin on June 20 had a maximum wind speed of over 210 mph. Wind speeds in a tornado need to reach at least 200 mph for it to be classified as an EF-5, the highest rating on the Enhanced Fujita Scale.
The initial estimate in the days after it happened was an EF-3.
Authorities said two men and a woman died during the tornado, which caused extensive tree damage, tipped several train cars fully loaded with grain and lifted tanker cars. The NWS said one tanker car was thrown just over 475 feet.
The severe weather event also destroyed a farm in the area, with the foundation of at least one of its buildings "considered to be swept clean," according to the NWS.
According to officials, the tornado lasted just under 20 minutes, from 11:02 p.m. to 11:21 p.m., and created a 12-mile path of destruction from Enderlin to Alice, North Dakota.
Enderlin is around 57 miles southwest of Fargo, North Dakota.
The last confirmed EF-5 tornado in the U.S. touched down in Moore, Oklahoma, on May 20, 2013, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
The 2013 tornado had wind speeds of up to 200 mph. According to the NWS, it traveled over 14 miles, killed 24 people, injured over 200 others and damaged many structures.

source_articles.title: Linda S. Lumbert | 1943 - 2025 | Obituary - Miles Funeral Service
source_articles.body:
Memorial service
Saturday, Oct 11, 2025
10:00 AM
May 18, 1943 - October 3, 2025
Linda S. Lumbert, 82, of Winfield, Kansas, passed away Friday evening, October 3, 2025, at her home.
Born May 18, 1943, in Hardtner, Kansas, she was the daughter of Norwood and Roberta (Bryan) Freeman. She was raised in Lake City, Kansas and received her education in Medicine Lodge.
In 1958, she married Gerald L. Neighbors in Medicine Lodge. The couple had two children and later divorced. Linda began working at Binney & Smith in 1979.
She was united in marriage to Howard Byron Lumbert on July 17, 1982 at Hackney Community Baptist Church. Linda continued working at Binney & Smith for nearly 20 years, retiring when the plant closed in 1997. In addition to her career, Linda was a dedicated and loving wife, mother, and homemaker. Howard preceded her in death on December 30, 2022.
She was a founding member of New Hope Fellowship Church and recently was attending Central Baptist Church. She enjoyed sewing, making pies, and traveling with Howard and friends.
Her family includes her sons, Morse Neighbors and partner, Donna McClain of Winfield; Ross Lumbert and wife, Jana of Rose Hill; her daughters, Lisa Chrisman and husband, Joe of Winfield; Gayle Walker and husband, Brad of Chandler, TX; her grandchildren, Hollie Neighbors of Wichita; Kelly Jacques and husband, Martin of Lawrence; Levi Chrisman of Winfield; Rebecca Chrisman and fiance, Brandon Beyard of Winfield; John Ross Lumbert of Andover; Jared Lumbert and wife, Sabra of Rose Hill; Rachel Love and husband, Eric of Rose Hill; Kaitlyn Lumbert of Lyons; Waylon Lumbert of Winfield; Sarina Proctor of Kingwood, TX; Celina Banks of Houston, TX; and her great grandchildren, Emmy, Abe, Lucy, Bryon, Kevin, Isla, Scott, Ruth, Case Howard, and Delena.
In addition to her parents and husband, Linda was preceded in death by a sister Pat Naasz and a brother Bryan Freeman.
Memorial services will be held at 10:00 A.M., Saturday, October 11, 2025, at Central Baptist Church in Winfield under the direction of Miles Funeral Service. Interment will take place at Highland Cemetery at a later date.
A memorial has been established in Linda’s name for Central Baptist Church. Contributions may be made through the funeral home.
To send a flower arrangement in memory of

source_articles.title: The Nikkei Average fell by 215 yen, marking its first decline in five days amid caution over short-term overheating = Afternoon session on the 8th. - 富途牛牛
source_articles.body:
In the afternoon session eight days later, the Nikkei Stock Average fell by 215 yen and 89 sen to close at 47,734.99, marking its first decline in five days. Meanwhile, the TOPIX (Tokyo Stock Price Index) rose by 7.75 points to close at 3,235.66, extending its gains for the fourth consecutive day and setting a new record closing high for the third straight session. In the U.S. market on the 7th, the NY Dow continued its decline, while the Nasdaq Composite Index also reversed its upward trend. Japanese stocks initially saw strong selling pressure due to a pullback following sharp gains from recent trading activity. Although there was some recovery attributed to bargain hunting, upside buying remained limited. Subsequently, amid concerns about short-term overheating, the Nikkei Average remained subdued and dropped by 222.61 yen to 47,728.27 at 3:15 PM. Towards the end of trading, the index weakened further due to profit-taking after a streak of gains. The USD/JPY exchange rate remained range-bound around the 152.40-yen level.
The trading volume on the Tokyo Stock Exchange's Prime Market amounted to 2.21874 billion shares, with a total trading value of 5.8674 trillion yen. Among the listed issues, 557 stocks advanced, 999 declined, and 60 remained unchanged.
Among all 33 industry sectors, 19 declined and 14 advanced. Rubber product stocks such as Bridgestone (5108.T) and Hama Gomu (5101.T), as well as precision equipment stocks like Terumo (4543.T) and HOYA (7741.T), experienced declines. Pulp and paper stocks including Oji Holdings (3861.T) and Nippon Paper (3863.T), along with chemical stocks such as Shin-Etsu Chemical (4063.T) and Fujifilm Holdings (4901.T), were also weak. Information and communication stocks like KDDI (9433.T) and SoftBank Group (9984.T), as well as steel stocks including Nippon Steel (5401.T) and JFE Holdings (5411.T), showed softness. Real estate stocks like Mitsui Fudosan (8801.T) and Mitsubishi Estate (8802.T), along with land transportation stocks such as Tokyu Corporation (9005.T) and Central Japan Railway Company (9022.T), also underperformed. On the other hand, non-ferrous metal stocks like Furukawa Electric (5801.T) and Fujikura (5803.T), as well as marine products and agriculture stocks including Nissui (1332.T) and Sakata Seed (1377.T), performed strongly.
Elsewhere, Parco GH (2726.T), Ichigo (2337.T), M&A Research Institute (9552.T), Sunwells (9229.T), and TBASE (3415.T) declined. Conversely, Warabe-ya Nihon (2918.T), LinkUG (4446.T), Orion Breweries (409A.T), Sakata Seed (1377.T), and Mitsubishi Steel (5632.T) advanced.

source_articles.title: Japanese Stocks Surge on "Takaichi Trade": ETFs in Focus - TradingView
source_articles.body:
Japanese Stocks Surge on "Takaichi Trade": ETFs in Focus
Japan’s Nikkei 225 index surged more than 4% on Oct. 6, 2025, to hit an all-time high. The country’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party elected conservative Sanae Takaichi as its new leader on Saturday. The election positioned her to become the country’s first female prime minister, per CNBC.
The move sparked optimism over a potential revival in government spending and a continuation of loose monetary policy, per Reuters, as quoted on Yahoo Finance. The recent rally in the Japanese stock markets was helped by real estate, technology, and consumer cyclical shares.
Bond Yields and Yen React Sharply
The 30-year Japanese government bond (JGB) plunged, pushing its yield to a record high, per Reuters, while the two-year note yield fell amid expectations of delayed rate hikes by the Bank of Japan. The yen tumbled moderately against the U.S. dollar and dropped to historic lows versus the euro.
Takaichi’s Expansionist Agenda
Takaichi is viewed as the most expansionist candidate among the five contenders in the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) race, succeeding the hawkish Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba, per Reuters.
“The Nikkei was on course to reach as high as 48,000 by year-end, but because Takaichi was chosen as the LDP leader, it shot up toward that level already,” said Hitoshi Asaoka, chief strategist at Asset Management One, as quoted on Reuters.
As a candidate, Takaichi proposed enhancing investment in strategic business sectors, including artificial intelligence, semiconductors, nuclear fusion and defense, per the Reuters article.
ETFs to Gain
Against the aforementioned backdrop, below we highlight a few exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that could be potential winners.
Currency-Hedged Large-Cap ETFs
The rally in Japanese equities will likely boost demand for Japan-focused large-cap ETFs. The Nikkei is an export-heavy index and thus fares better in a falling yen environment. A weaker yen boosts the profitability of Japan's major export-oriented companies.
However, this also means that the U.S. dollar will likely gain strength against the yen. This makes the case for investing in a currency-hedged Japan large-cap ETF strong.
WisdomTree Japan Hedged Equity Fund DXJ, Xtrackers MSCI Japan Hedged Equity ETF DBJP and iShares Currency Hedged MSCI Japan ETF HEWJ are some of the ETFs that should gain ahead. DXJ was up 2.8% on Oct. 6, 2025.
Inverse Yen
ProShares UltraShort Yen YCS gained 3.8% on Oct. 6, 2025, on a falling yen. Note that hopes of easier monetary policy weighed on the yen ETF Invesco CurrencyShares Japanese Yen Trust FXY. The ETF FXY slumped 1.9% on Oct. 6, 2025.
This article originally published on Zacks Investment Research (zacks.com).
Zacks Investment Research
